```{r}
# ============================================================================

library(sysfonts)
library(dplyr)
```

```{r}
# ============================================================================
# DU BOIS COLOR PALETTE
# Based on his distinctive use of bold, symbolic colors
# ============================================================================

dubois_colors <- list(
  # Signature colors from Paris Exposition charts
  black = "#000000",           # Strong black for emphasis
  red = "#dc143c",             # Crimson red (struggle, blood)
  gold = "#ffc04d",            # Gold/yellow (hope, prosperity)
  blue = "#4e79a7",            # Steel blue (stability)
  green = "#7fc97f",           # Soft green (growth)
  brown = "#d4a574",           # Tan/beige (earth, labor)
  pink = "#fbb4ae",            # Soft pink
  purple = "#bc80bd",          # Muted purple
  navy = "#2f4858",            # Deep navy
  cream = "#f5e6d3",           # Cream/parchment background
  
  # Extended palette for complex charts
  categorical = c(
    "#dc143c",  # Red
    "#000000",  # Black
    "#ffc04d",  # Gold
    "#4e79a7",  # Blue
    "#7fc97f",  # Green
    "#d4a574",  # Brown
    "#bc80bd",  # Purple
    "#fbb4ae"   # Pink
  ),
  
  # Specific palettes for common themes
  # Population/demographic
  population = c("#dc143c", "#4e79a7", "#ffc04d", "#7fc97f"),
  
  # Economic status
  economic = c("#000000", "#d4a574", "#ffc04d", "#7fc97f"),
  
  # Education levels
  education = c("#4e79a7", "#7fc97f", "#ffc04d", "#dc143c"),
  
  # Background colors
  background = "#f5e6d3",      # Aged paper/parchment
  background_alt = "#faf4ea",  # Lighter alternative
  
  # Sequential scales
  red_scale = c("#fbb4ae", "#fc8d62", "#e34a33", "#b30000", "#67000d"),
  blue_scale = c("#c6dbef", "#9ecae1", "#6baed6", "#3182bd", "#08519c"),
  gold_scale = c("#fff7bc", "#fee391", "#fec44f", "#fe9929", "#cc4c02")
)

# Function to access Du Bois colors
dubois_palette <- function(palette = "categorical", n = NULL, reverse = FALSE) {
  pal <- dubois_colors[[palette]]
  
  if (reverse) pal <- rev(pal)
  
  if (!is.null(n)) {
    if (n <= length(pal)) {
      pal <- pal[1:n]
    } else {
      pal <- colorRampPalette(pal)(n)
    }
  }
  
  return(pal)
}
```

```{r}
# ============================================================================
# MAIN DU BOIS THEME
# ============================================================================

theme_dubois <- function(base_size = 11,
                         title_family = "Crimson",
                         body_family = "Public Sans",
                         base_line_size = 0.75,
                         grid = "y") {
  
  ret <- theme_minimal(base_size = base_size,
                       base_family = body_family,
                       base_line_size = base_line_size)
  
  ret <- ret + theme(
    # Plot background - characteristic parchment color
    plot.background = element_rect(
      fill = dubois_colors$background,
      color = dubois_colors$black,
      size = 2  # Bold border like Du Bois
    ),
    
    panel.background = element_rect(
      fill = dubois_colors$background,
      color = NA
    ),
    
    # Panel border - strong black lines
    panel.border = element_rect(
      fill = NA,
      color = dubois_colors$black,
      size = 1.5
    ),
    
    # Title - hand-lettered style, centered
    plot.title = element_text(
      family = title_family,
      size = rel(1.4),
      face = "bold",
      hjust = 0.5,  # Centered like Du Bois
      vjust = 1,
      margin = margin(b = 10, t = 10),
      color = dubois_colors$black,
      lineheight = 1.1
    ),
    
    # Subtitle - often used for data source
    plot.subtitle = element_text(
      family = body_family,
      size = rel(0.9),
      hjust = 0.5,
      margin = margin(b = 15, t = 5),
      color = dubois_colors$black,
      face = "plain"
    ),
    
    # Caption - attribution
    plot.caption = element_text(
      family = body_family,
      size = rel(0.75),
      hjust = 0.5,
      margin = margin(t = 15),
      color = dubois_colors$black,
      face = "italic"
    ),
    
    plot.title.position = "plot",
    plot.caption.position = "plot",
    
    # Grid - minimal, strong when present
    panel.grid.major = element_line(
      color = dubois_colors$black,
      size = 0.5
    ),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    
    # Axes - bold, clear
    axis.title = element_text(
      family = body_family,
      size = rel(0.9),
      color = dubois_colors$black,
      face = "bold"
    ),
    axis.title.x = element_text(margin = margin(t = 10)),
    axis.title.y = element_text(margin = margin(r = 10), angle = 90),
    
    axis.text = element_text(
      family = body_family,
      size = rel(0.85),
      color = dubois_colors$black,
      face = "bold"  # Du Bois used bold text
    ),
    
    # Strong axis lines
    axis.line = element_line(
      color = dubois_colors$black,
      size = 1
    ),
    
    axis.ticks = element_line(
      color = dubois_colors$black,
      size = 0.75
    ),
    axis.ticks.length = unit(4, "pt"),
    
    # Legend - clean and bold
    legend.position = "bottom",
    legend.justification = "center",
    legend.direction = "horizontal",
    legend.background = element_rect(
      fill = dubois_colors$background,
      color = dubois_colors$black,
      size = 1
    ),
    legend.title = element_text(
      family = title_family,
      size = rel(0.9),
      face = "bold",
      color = dubois_colors$black
    ),
    legend.text = element_text(
      family = body_family,
      size = rel(0.85),
      color = dubois_colors$black,
      face = "bold"
    ),
    legend.key = element_rect(
      fill = dubois_colors$background,
      color = dubois_colors$black,
      size = 0.5
    ),
    legend.key.size = unit(1.2, "lines"),
    legend.margin = margin(10, 10, 10, 10),
    legend.box.margin = margin(5, 5, 5, 5),
    
    # Strip text for facets
    strip.text = element_text(
      family = title_family,
      size = rel(1),
      face = "bold",
      color = dubois_colors$black,
      margin = margin(5, 5, 5, 5)
    ),
    strip.background = element_rect(
      fill = alpha(dubois_colors$gold, 0.3),
      color = dubois_colors$black,
      size = 1
    ),
    
    # Margins - generous like his charts
    plot.margin = margin(20, 20, 20, 20),
    
    complete = TRUE
  )
  
  # Grid options
  if (grid == "none") {
    ret <- ret + theme(
      panel.grid.major = element_blank(),
      panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
    )
  } else if (grid == "y") {
    ret <- ret + theme(
      panel.grid.major.x = element_blank()
    )
  } else if (grid == "x") {
    ret <- ret + theme(
      panel.grid.major.y = element_blank()
    )
  }
  
  return(ret)
}
```

```{r}
# ============================================================================
# VARIANT: MINIMALIST DU BOIS (for spiral/circular charts)
# ============================================================================

theme_dubois_minimal <- function(base_size = 11) {
  theme_dubois(base_size = base_size, grid = "none") +
    theme(
      panel.border = element_blank(),
      axis.line = element_blank(),
      axis.ticks = element_blank(),
      axis.text = element_blank(),
      axis.title = element_blank(),
      panel.grid = element_blank()
    )
}
```

```{r}
# ============================================================================
# COLOR SCALES
# ============================================================================

scale_color_dubois <- function(palette = "categorical", reverse = FALSE, ...) {
  pal <- dubois_palette(palette = palette, reverse = reverse)
  
  ggplot2::discrete_scale(
    "colour",
    paste0("dubois_", palette),
    palette = function(n) {
      if (n > length(pal)) {
        colorRampPalette(pal)(n)
      } else {
        pal[1:n]
      }
    },
    ...
  )
}

scale_fill_dubois <- function(palette = "categorical", reverse = FALSE, ...) {
  pal <- dubois_palette(palette = palette, reverse = reverse)
  
  ggplot2::discrete_scale(
    "fill",
    paste0("dubois_", palette),
    palette = function(n) {
      if (n > length(pal)) {
        colorRampPalette(pal)(n)
      } else {
        pal[1:n]
      }
    },
    ...
  )
}

# Continuous scales
scale_color_dubois_c <- function(palette = "red_scale", reverse = FALSE, ...) {
  pal <- dubois_palette(palette = palette, reverse = reverse)
  ggplot2::scale_color_gradientn(colors = pal, ...)
}

scale_fill_dubois_c <- function(palette = "red_scale", reverse = FALSE, ...) {
  pal <- dubois_palette(palette = palette, reverse = reverse)
  ggplot2::scale_fill_gradientn(colors = pal, ...)
}
```

```{r}
# ============================================================================
# EXAMPLE 1: SIMPLE BAR CHART (Du Bois style)
# ============================================================================

# Occupations data (inspired by Du Bois)
df_occupations <- data.frame(
  occupation = c("Agriculture", "Domestic Service", "Manufacturing", 
                 "Trade", "Professional", "Other"),
  percentage = c(44.2, 21.5, 12.8, 8.3, 3.7, 9.5),
  year = "1890"
)

p1 <- ggplot(df_occupations, aes(x = reorder(occupation, percentage), y = percentage)) +
  geom_col(
    fill = dubois_colors$red,
    color = dubois_colors$black,
    width = 0.7,
    size = 1.5  # Bold outlines
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(label = paste0(percentage, "%")),
    hjust = -0.2,
    family = "Public Sans",
    fontface = "bold",
    size = 4,
    color = dubois_colors$black
  ) +
  coord_flip() +
  scale_y_continuous(
    expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.15)),
    breaks = seq(0, 50, 10),
    labels = function(x) paste0(x, "%")
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "OCCUPATIONS OF NEGROES IN GEORGIA.",
    subtitle = "1890",
    caption = "Data from U.S. Census",
    x = NULL,
    y = "PERCENT"
  ) +
  theme_dubois(grid = "x")

print(p1)
```

```{r}
# ============================================================================
```
```{r}
# EXAMPLE 5: SPIRAL BAR CHART - "CITY AND RURAL POPULATION"
# This is Du Bois' famous spiral visualization!
# ============================================================================

# Create data for spiral chart
df_spiral <- data.frame(
  decade = c("1790", "1800", "1810", "1820", "1830", "1840", 
             "1850", "1860", "1870", "1880", "1890"),
  rural = c(97, 96, 95, 94, 92, 89, 85, 80, 74, 68, 64),
  city = c(3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 11, 15, 20, 26, 32, 36)
)

# Calculate spiral coordinates
n_points <- nrow(df_spiral)
df_spiral$angle <- seq(0, 4 * pi, length.out = n_points)  # 2 full rotations
df_spiral$index <- 1:n_points

# Create separate data for rural and city
df_spiral_long <- tidyr::pivot_longer(
  df_spiral,
  cols = c(rural, city),
  names_to = "type",
  values_to = "percentage"
)

# Calculate radial position (percentage determines radius)
df_spiral_long$radius_start <- ifelse(df_spiral_long$type == "rural", 
                                      df_spiral_long$index * 0.5, 
                                      df_spiral_long$index * 0.5 + df_spiral_long$percentage/100 * 3)
df_spiral_long$radius_end <- ifelse(df_spiral_long$type == "rural",
                                    df_spiral_long$index * 0.5 + df_spiral_long$percentage/100 * 3,
                                    df_spiral_long$index * 0.5 + 3)

# Convert to Cartesian coordinates for bars
create_spiral_bar <- function(angle, r_start, r_end, width = 0.3) {
  angles <- seq(angle - width/2, angle + width/2, length.out = 50)
  data.frame(
    x = c(r_start * cos(angles), rev(r_end * cos(angles))),
    y = c(r_start * sin(angles), rev(r_end * sin(angles)))
  )
}

# Create all spiral segments
spiral_segments <- lapply(1:nrow(df_spiral_long), function(i) {
  row <- df_spiral_long[i, ]
  seg <- create_spiral_bar(row$angle, row$radius_start, row$radius_end)
  seg$decade <- row$decade
  seg$type <- row$type
  seg$percentage <- row$percentage
  seg$group_id <- i
  seg
})

df_spiral_plot <- do.call(rbind, spiral_segments)

# Create label positions
df_labels <- df_spiral %>%
  mutate(
    x_label = (index * 0.5 + 1.5) * cos(angle),
    y_label = (index * 0.5 + 1.5) * sin(angle)
  )

# Create the spiral plot
p5_spiral <- ggplot() +
  # Draw spiral segments
  geom_polygon(
    data = df_spiral_plot,
    aes(x = x, y = y, group = group_id, fill = type),
    color = dubois_colors$black,
    size = 1.2
  ) +
  # Add decade labels
  geom_text(
    data = df_labels,
    aes(x = x_label, y = y_label, label = decade),
    family = "Public Sans",
    fontface = "bold",
    size = 3.5,
    color = dubois_colors$black
  ) +
  # Add percentage labels at specific points
  geom_text(
    data = df_labels %>% filter(decade %in% c("1790", "1830", "1870", "1890")),
    aes(
      x = (index * 0.5 + 3.5) * cos(angle),
      y = (index * 0.5 + 3.5) * sin(angle),
      label = paste0(city, "%\nCITY")
    ),
    family = "Public Sans",
    fontface = "bold",
    size = 2.5,
    color = dubois_colors$black,
    lineheight = 0.9
  ) +
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = c(
      "rural" = dubois_colors$green,
      "city" = dubois_colors$red
    ),
    labels = c("CITY", "RURAL"),
    name = NULL
  ) +
  coord_equal() +
  labs(
    title = "CITY AND RURAL POPULATION.\n1790-1890.",
    caption = "Spiral chart showing the shift from rural to urban living"
  ) +
  theme_dubois_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = rel(1.5), margin = margin(b = 20, t = 20)),
    plot.caption = element_text(size = rel(0.8), margin = margin(t = 20)),
    legend.position = "bottom",
    legend.background = element_rect(
      fill = dubois_colors$background,
      color = dubois_colors$black,
      size = 1
    ),
    legend.text = element_text(size = rel(1), face = "bold"),
    legend.key.size = unit(1.5, "lines")
  )

print(p5_spiral)
```

```{r}
# ============================================================================
# EXAMPLE 6: IMPROVED SPIRAL (More accurate to original)
# ============================================================================

# Simpler spiral approach
df_spiral_simple <- df_spiral
df_spiral_simple$angle_deg <- seq(0, 720, length.out = nrow(df_spiral_simple))
df_spiral_simple$radius <- seq(2, 6, length.out = nrow(df_spiral_simple))

# Calculate bar endpoints
df_spiral_simple <- df_spiral_simple %>%
  mutate(
    angle_rad = angle_deg * pi / 180,
    # Rural bar (inner)
    rural_x_start = radius * cos(angle_rad),
    rural_y_start = radius * sin(angle_rad),
    rural_x_end = (radius + rural/25) * cos(angle_rad),
    rural_y_end = (radius + rural/25) * sin(angle_rad),
    # City bar (outer)
    city_x_start = (radius + rural/25) * cos(angle_rad),
    city_y_start = (radius + rural/25) * sin(angle_rad),
    city_x_end = (radius + (rural + city)/25) * cos(angle_rad),
    city_y_end = (radius + (rural + city)/25) * sin(angle_rad)
  )

p6_spiral <- ggplot(df_spiral_simple) +
  # Rural segments (green)
  geom_segment(
    aes(x = rural_x_start, y = rural_y_start,
        xend = rural_x_end, yend = rural_y_end),
    color = dubois_colors$green,
    size = 12,
    lineend = "butt"
  ) +
  # City segments (red)
  geom_segment(
    aes(x = city_x_start, y = city_y_start,
        xend = city_x_end, yend = city_y_end),
    color = dubois_colors$red,
    size = 12,
    lineend = "butt"
  ) +
  # Decade labels
  geom_text(
    aes(x = (radius - 0.8) * cos(angle_rad),
        y = (radius - 0.8) * sin(angle_rad),
        label = decade),
    family = "Public Sans",
    fontface = "bold",
    size = 3.5
  ) +
  # Percentage labels
  geom_text(
    data = df_spiral_simple %>% filter(decade %in% c("1790", "1840", "1890")),
    aes(x = (radius + 5) * cos(angle_rad),
        y = (radius + 5) * sin(angle_rad),
        label = paste0(city, "%")),
    family = "Public Sans",
    fontface = "bold",
    size = 3,
    color = dubois_colors$red
  ) +
  coord_equal(xlim = c(-12, 12), ylim = c(-12, 12)) +
  labs(
    title = "CITY AND RURAL POPULATION.\n1790-1890."
  ) +
  theme_dubois_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = rel(1.6), margin = margin(b = 15, t = 15)),
    plot.background = element_rect(
      fill = dubois_colors$background,
      color = dubois_colors$black,
      size = 2
    )
  ) +
  # Add legend manually
  annotate("rect", xmin = -4, xmax = -2, ymin = -11, ymax = -10,
           fill = dubois_colors$green, color = dubois_colors$black, size = 0.5) +
  annotate("text", x = -1, y = -10.5, label = "RURAL", hjust = 0,
           family = "Public Sans", fontface = "bold", size = 4) +
  annotate("rect", xmin = -4, xmax = -2, ymin = -9.5, ymax = -8.5,
           fill = dubois_colors$red, color = dubois_colors$black, size = 0.5) +
  annotate("text", x = -1, y = -9, label = "CITY", hjust = 0,
           family = "Public Sans", fontface = "bold", size = 4)

print(p6_spiral)
```

```{r}
  # Create circular segments
  geom_segment(

        color = decade),
    size = 2,
    arrow = arrow(length = unit(0.3, "cm"), type = "closed")
  ) +
  # Add points at ends
  geom_point(
    aes(x = city_x_end, y = city_y_end, size = city),
    color = dubois_colors$red,
    fill = dubois_colors$background,
    shape = 21,
    stroke = 2
  ) +
  # Labels
  geom_text(
    aes(x = city_x_end * 1.15, y = city_y_end * 1.15, label = decade),
    family = "Public Sans",
    fontface = "bold",
    size = 3.5
  ) +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = colorRampPalette(c(dubois_colors$navy, dubois_colors$red))(11)
  ) +
  scale_size_continuous(range = c(3, 15)) +
  coord_equal() +
  labs(
    title = "GROWTH OF CITY POPULATION.\n1790-1890.",
    subtitle = "Arrow length and point size represent percentage in cities"
  ) +
  theme_dubois_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = rel(1.5), margin = margin(b = 10, t = 20)),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = rel(0.9), margin = margin(b = 20)),
    legend.position = "none"
  )

print(p7_radial)
```

```{r}
save_dubois_plot <- function(plot, filename, width = 8, height = 10, dpi = 300) {
  ggsave(
    filename = filename,
    plot = plot,
    width = width,
    height = height,
    dpi = dpi,
    bg = dubois_colors$background
  )
  message("✓ Du Bois style plot saved: ", filename)
}
```
